I saw a very interesting lecture of Andrew Szydlo about combustion and he stated that a uniform mixture of fuel and air should result in complete combustion, which manifests as a blue flame, as we can see e.g. in Bunsen burner. In your video, we can see most of the flame is actually orange, which would indicate incomplete combustion. Despite all the efforts to improve combustion engines, we can see the whole process is actually still quite ineffective. Interesting... :)

Great video! But fuel in an engine DOES NOT EXPLODE, it burns very rapidly with a positive flame front. Call it "firing" not exploding [smile].  If it did actually explode, it would not be long before the pistons, rings, wrist pins, connecting rods, bearings, and crankshaft would be destroyed. Knocks and pings are bad for engines as well, but they are not from explosions, more from timing errors, carbon build up, and fuel issues. As I watched this video a second time, I came to think of an episode of Dogfights, a series on Discovery Channel many years ago. It was an interview with a George Sutcliffe who was a P-47 Thunderbolt Pilot during WW2. He told a story about a flight of four P-47's getting jumped by 40 Messerschmidt Me-109's and the Colonel who was lead said they'd better climb into the cloud ceiling. These P-47's were fitted with the new Paddle Props and they had a button for Water Injection. I have seen Water Injection in other engines as well, spraying a Water-Methanol mixture in to cool the cylinder walls so that more fuel and air can fit in with each intake stroke.

It's easy to understand the physical concept of Water Injection, but it's hard to envision how this could increase engine performance as tremendously as it did. So, if @SmarterEveryDay is revisiting the See Through Engine in Slow Motion, I wonder if it is possible for these ingenious engine tinkerers to fit it with a Water-Methanol injection system to see how effective it really is on engine performance, and if it gives a visibly better effect on the combustion?

We could reliably get ~94% efficiency with a closed loop superheated steam system harvesting exhaust heat from a small jet engine and got just below 96% efficiency in some ideal test cases. The main limiting factors were that the discs had to be designed to stretch uniformly without distorting at ~40k RPM and that the gaps between the disks had to be designed for an incredibly specific set of operating parameters (steam temp, pressure, velocity, etc.). I just realized, that timing importance with the spark gap is kind of like pushing someone on a swing, where you want to prepare to push right before they completely stop moving. Too late, and you’re having to chase them down in the swing, but too soon, and you’re essentially stealing from yourself earlier. Also, this explains why knocking in an engine is so bad. It’s pushing back against all the piston’s forward momentum, and it’s also essentially jolting the engine into reverse. When I discussed my electric drill manual with my dad and mentioned that they said not to switch directions on the drill until it had come to a full stop, he immediately reinforced the manual’s statement  vehemently. It’s like hitting the engine with double the force of another engine from a complete stop: very bad for all mechanical system involved.

A 4 stroke engine works the exact same way as your girlfriend.
1. SUCK = Intake
2. SQUEEZE = Compression
3. BANG = Power
4. BLOW = Exhaust

Another helpful bit of information regarding the "back pressure" Destin mentioned at the end of the video...
Once again - your engine is exactly like your girlfriend...

The "IN" hole is much larger than the "OUT" hole.
In an engine, the INTAKE side of the engine - which inhales nice fresh air for the engine to "eat" is much larger than the exhaust tube that the old, used air the engine had already consumed is pushed out of.

In your girlfriend, her mouth is much larger than her... Well let's just say it, her butt hole. The only difference is that her exhaust better not be louder than her intake. If it is, find a new girlfriend.

Engines are just like people.
Love your engine.
Take your engine to the car Dr regularly for a check up.
Change your oil and make sure it is well lubricated. Oil is literally the blood of the engine, so make sure it has nice, good, healthy blood... Not blood that's as black as your mothers soul.
Change your anti freeze at least once every few years... Because just like people, if an engine gets too hot, it dies.

If you treat your engine as if it were a person, your engine will last forever.

Sincerely,
A Mechanic

For those that don't know, a small 4 stroke
engine will spark every time the piston rises,
just because that is an easier design. This
is called the "lost spark" system. Most newer
cars do the same thing. If you have a V6,
and it has a coil pack, like the 200* Taurus,
they have 3 coils in that pack. Each coil
drives 2 spark plugs, and go off just before
top dead center, for both. One is used, the
other is the "lost spark." (The next revolution,
that lost spark is at the other plug connected
to that coil.)

They aren’t explosions. They are controlled burns and in fact, if there were no exhaust opening, there would be no loud popping sound that we associate with explosions. It is the sudden release of high pressure gas that makes the sound of an “explosion”.. Explosions (detonation) will destroy any engine fast. But I do give him the benefit of the doubt that he is aware of this and just used the common though false description that most people think of when describing an engines sound.

It is NOT an explosion! There is a huge difference between combustion and detonation. Under the wrong conditions detonation of the fuel/air mixture can occur, but it is completely uncontrolled, makes very little power, and if it goes on long enough it will destroy the engine. Engines are designed around a known, controlled rate of combustion of the fuel. Any engine with "little explosions" going on is not only useless for doing any work, it's not going to be an engine very long.

I know this video is old but id just like to point out, the spark timing is so much more critical than you seem to think. You want the gas mixture to combust, NOT explode.keeping a safe combustion relies on the air / fuel ratio and the spark timing. an explosion happens sometimes, and its commonly known as "spark knock". In modern engines, there are actually little sensors that measure the vibration or sound pressure, and their sole purpose is to listen for spark knock, so that it can tell the computer to adjust the timing (or flash the check engine light if it can't fix itself by adjusting the timing) great video btw destin, keep killin it!

While you've got the theory down, due to the time required for events, there's a lot more going on here

The intake valve actually opens Before Top Dead Center (BTDC) on the exhaust stroke, while the exhaust valve is still open. This is called valve overlap
1 Allows more time to fill the cylinder
2 Scavenging: The exhaust charge leaving the cylinder creates a low pressure area (vacuum) behind it which pulls in more fuel at a higher velocity
3 Incoming intake charge helps expel exhaust gasses

Atmospheric pressure at sea level is 14.7PSI. The piston traveling down on the intake stroke creates vacuum. Atmospheric pressure combined with vacuum forces more air and fuel into the cylinder at higher velocity

Intake valve actually closes After Bottom Dead Center (ABDC) during compression stroke because the cylinder is still a low pressure area, enabling atmospheric pressure to continue forcing in additional air and fuel. That, and inertia.

In most cars, the spark initiates while the piston is approximately 30-40 degrees (of crankshaft rotation) BTDC and the event of the spark can last roughly 3-7 degrees.

Although the air/fuel ratio is compressed to nearly spontaneous combustion, the burning mixture really doesn't start to increase the cylinder pressure until 10-15 degrees BTDC.

The entire fuel burn in a gasoline engine lasts roughly 60 degrees. The gasses are still expanding and creating pressure which is forcing the piston towards BDC.

Because we're talking about events which last for milliseconds, even at a low idle, and because there is still a small amount of pressure remaining in the cylinder, the exhaust valve begins to open several degrees BBDC.

The still expanding gasses with negligible pressures start to escape before the piston begins upward travel on the exhaust stroke.

The most efficient, non-performance engines achieve 70-80% volumetric efficiency meaning for every 10 cubic centimeters of cylinder area, only 7-8 cubic centimeters of air and fuel enter.

Quick mathematic side bar: The area of a circle is Pi*R^2 (Pie R Squared. To find the area of a cylinder, you then multiply that number by the length of the piston stroke (not the connecting rod).

If you have a 5 centimeter cylinder bore diameter, the radius is 2.500 centimeters

2.5*2.5=6.25
6.25*3.14159=19.6349375

If you multiply that number by a piston stroke distance of say 3 centimeters, you come up with displacement at 58.9 cubic centimeters

For the sake of argument, if we take 75% as our volumetric efficiency, we end up with an engine that inhales 44.178cc.

A "violent" or "aggressive" camshaft profile combined with carefully enlarged and smoothed out intake and exhaust ports and larger valves might increase that V.E. number to say 79-82% in a reliable build combination.

This is where boost comes into play:

If your engine crankshaft has a pulley on it, it can use a belt to drive a Supercharger AKA blower. It basically compresses and pressurizes a larger volume of air to force into the cylinder.

If your exhaust gasses pass over a turbine fan, the fan will spin on a shaft. If that shaft is supported on bearings and has an impeller aka compressor where on the opposite end, it can draw in and compress more air to be forced into the engine.

That's called a turbocharger.

In a boosted application, with everything else optimized for performance, you can see V.E. numbers significantly higher than 100%


Anyways, back to our lawnmower engine
This is a dinosaur design called a flat head. Obvious name. The combustion chamber includes the space above the valves which are located in the block.

A modern, so called over head valve design moves the valves into the head and directly over the piston. With the spark plug directly centered over the piston, the burn of the fuel and the pressure of the burn is directed over top of the cylinder. Far less milliseconds of burn time are wasted as the charge burns closer and closer to the piston.

Using a hemispherical (Hemi) combustion chamber maximizes this effect, fully directing the force of the combustion burn onto the crown of the piston.

While yes, it is an explosion I do like to point out the difference between deflagration and detonation. Deflagration is what we want in an engine. It's a controlled burn with a flame front propagating at subsonic speeds. Detonation on the other hand is the flame front traveling at supersonic speeds. Detonation/knock/pinging can be caused by high compression coupled with too low of octane fuel (octane is a fun topic...RON vs MON vs AKI...), carbon deposits generating hot spots (and also raising compression), spark issues, etc. The basic problem with detonation is that the energy of the fuel is released too rapidly. It's pretty much like hitting the piston with a hammer which is damaging to the piston, rings rods, main bearings, heck even the cylinder head and block could be damaged!

So yeah, dont think of a bunch of little explosions going "bang bang bang" in your engine but more "woosh." Also, consider at only 3,000 RPM your pistons are going up and down 50 times per second and the whole process is happening 25 times per second per cylinder in your vehicle. Even at idle, it's probably turning around 13 times per second. It's awesome!

so you still don't understand how a 4 stroke engine works.  got it.  there is no explosion.  when there is an explosion inside an engine the engine is destroyed, rods pop out, intake manifolds blow off.   after the compression stroke the spark ignites the air/fuel mixture which causes the it to burn......not explode but burn......and if that's all that happened the engine still would not run.  what makes the engine run is when the air/fuel mixture burns it heats the nitrogen in the cylinder which causes the nitrogen to expand and force the piston down.  this is why NOS makes big horsepower.  it adds O2 which allows you to add more fuel which makes a bigger fire and it adds more N2 which results in more N2 to expand and create more down force on the piston.  so NOW you're smarter.

Calling it an explosion is disingenuous.  Compression of the fuel air mixture makes the fuel and oxygen in the mixture more volatile which will make it burn faster and it puts as much air into as small as space as possible.  When the fuel and oxygen burn in the mixture it heats up the air which then expands pushing down the piston.  The piston isn't blown down by explosions, it is pushed down by expanding air.

Dear Americans, the correct names for each stroke are:
1. Injection (not intake)
2. Compression
3. Combustion (not power)
4. Exhaust

... as far as I remember from high school Engineering Physics lessons

You know what this also demonstrates beautifully is the scavenging effect an exhaust system is supposed to create. No doubt a full exhaust system in a automobile is different than this setup, but you can see how the exhaust gases are quickly sucked out when that exhaust valve starts to open. The piston is just starting it's way back up, but the exhaust gases are sucked out well before the exhaust stroke is completed.

Auto shop 101 basics.  Gasoline does not "explode" in an engine, it burns smoothly.  If the engine had continuous explosions there would be a rattling sound called spark knock, a condition which could quickly destroy an engine. Another fact to make you smarter about the internal workings of a four stroke engine.

One I would like to point out to a lot of people that may not know it . When you have a crankshaft triggered magneto it fires on every revolution so it fires on the compression stroke TDC  and on TDC at the end of the exhaust stroke because they take the timing of the crankshaft. matter of fact a lot of new cars today have crankshaft triggered ignition so they fire twice, just thought I’d point that out.

Hey Destin, another cool video but...I have to correct something you’re saying often in this one and a few others. It may be geeky hair-splitting, but I figure you’re the kinda guy who’d want to know. So, here goes:

You repeatedly refer to the combustion event as an explosion. Well, it’s not. My Mechanical Engineering doctorate was in combustion science, in case you need a credibility check. Technically, the flame in the engine cylinder, the potato gun, and etc. is a DEFLAGRATION, not a DETONATION. And the latter is what we mean by an “explosion.”

What’s the difference? In a deflagration, the speed at which the flame front propagates is subsonic; for a detonation, it’s supersonic. The shockwave associated with a detonation comes with an overpressure behind it, and it’s that overpressure that has the, um, explosive force. That‘s why explosions blow out windows, knock people off their feet, and so on. In a deflagration, the subsonic propagation of the flame front doesn’t cause any of that; it’s a whole lot MILDER of an event. And that’s what we want in an engine!

If you’re wondering, (because I know you’re that kinda guy, too!) deflagrations CAN transition to detonations, if conditions are right. That never happens in an engine to my knowledge, though. No shockwave, no explosion. Just smooth (albeit rapid) subsonic propagation fo the flame front across / through the combustion chamber.

With the power of the internet at most peoples finger tips it never ceases to amaze me how many people get this simple fact wrong. The fuel in a correctly running internal combustion engine does not explode! It burns. There is a significant difference. In older cars sometimes you would hear engine knock under hard acceleration. That's the fuel air mixture exploding. If it happens often enough it typically breaks the pistons by punching a hole in the top of them and then you need a new engine. The pistons are not the only part that gets damaged, they're just the first ones to fail. You never hear knock in newer cars since the introduction of knock sensors and electronic engine management systems. In the portion of the video that shows the single cylinder engine running in slow motion you can clearly see the flame front starting where the spark occurs and spreading across the combustion chamber and on into the cylinder. It's a perfect example of a controlled burn. Even the animation shows the flame front starting at the spark plug and propagating into the combustion chamber and then on into the cylinder. It a relatively slow burn NOT, not an explosion.

Great video!!!  But ;)  running engine on propane LPG does not make your engine last longer although here in Europe cost half compere to petrol.  Problem is propane burns slower so exhaust valve opens when gas still burns that burns the valve and valve seat that leads to  VSR - Valve Seat Recession. To reduce VSR lpg converted cars use valve lubricants like flashlube,  JLM but it is not actually 100% proven that those real works.  Key to success is often lpg instalation servicing and making sure that system does not run lean.  Big thanks to Everett for sharing his passion 👍

There are no explosions in an engine. It is a controlled burn of the air fuel mixture. An explosion would be an uncontrolled and violent expanse of gases which would very likely damage the engine, which in engines could be called detonation. A controlled burn produces an even and constant pressure upon the cylinder which allows for a smooth power delivery and not one shock force.

If anyone wants to know how the valves open and close there's this thing called a camshaft and it has little things called lobes on it that push something called a rocker arm down which opens the valves. The way the piston moves is this thing called a crankshaft which the connecting rod is attached to with the piston on top. The way the engine starts running is when you turn over key the starter turns over your crankshaft and that makes your piston move, then the momentum from the explosion pushes the piston down and back up and the cycle keeps going. Learning about the theory behind four stroke engines in high school is actually a big part of what led me to later go to college to be a mechanical engineer after serving in the Army.

What has always amazed me about four stroke engines is the timing and how perfect it has to be to get the optimal performance out of them. That and it always amazed me how the engine will power itself after a small starting boost via a pull cord, a crank, or a starter motor. Small gas engines, in how they produce their own timed spark, pull their own fuel, drive their own lubrication mechanism, all in such a small package was always impressive to me.

Of anything to take away from this is time, not just timing but time (seconds, miliseconds, microseconds, etc.)
Intake, Compression, Power, Exhaust... those four strokes happen in the blink of an eye at idle in your standard car (~1,000 rpm)
Now take that concept of speed and multiply it by 15,000 (2017 rev limit for an F1 car).... that cycle is happening at a mind blowing speed...
Talk about precision engineering, math, science and technology.

Modern car engines the exhaust valve opens before the piston gets to the bottom of the stroke.  Allowing the exhaust gasses to cool off creating a fraction of a vacuum helping draw the piston back up the cylinder.  This is one of the reasons that the asian cars were so much mmore fuel efficient in the early 1980's over the american big 3 (Ford Chevy Dodge).

The video clearly shows that the fuel/ Air mixture does NOT explode. The process is combustion. The combustion process starts at the ignition point [spark plug] & a flame front moves across or through the fuel mixture. If the fuel mix exploded every time [known variously as detonation, pinging or pinking] the engine would soon destroy itself, usually by melting a hole in the piston. So please, stop telling people that the fuel mixture "explodes" It does NOT.  TNT explodes, fuel air mix in an internal combustion engine combusts.

Maybe someone else has mentioned this but their are actually two times that the spark is introduced. Once during the compression stroke and then a second time during the exhaust stroke. The second spark is the there to help burn any residual fuel before it is exhausted and also prepares a fresh chamber for the next intake of fuel/air.

Like the powder in a rifle round, the fuel in an internal combustion engine does NOT explode. Hand grenades explode, bombs explode & so does TNT, but the powder in a rifle round & the fuel in the combustion chamber BURNS. The flame front was clearly seen in the video & in real life it moves through the fuel air mix very quickly.
An explosion is the instantaneous & spontaneous combustion of the WHOLE combustible mixture & if that happened, the plastic head would be blown off the top of the engine in short order. When it happens in a real engine [variously called pinging, pinking, detonation or knock] as a result of wrong fuel and/or other factors it usually destroys pistons. In rifles, the explosion usually causes rifle damage/destruction & injury.
The fuel DOES NOT EXPLODE in normal conditions.

I might've wished a little more detail on how it transfers into constant movement, but I think I figured it out.
Firstly importantly, you need initial momentum, for the engine to get rolling. But that momentum comes from the outside. Just like at 5:15, or basically like the first cars having a windup at the front.
Secondly after a cylinder has been pushed down through the explosion, that momentum carries over to it moving back up ,and repeating the cycle, and as long as there is fuel, that momentum will repeat without external input. Meaning you don't need to wind up the motor continuously.

An internal combustion engine derives its power from heat, not from explosions. As the air is heated from the fire it expands and increases in pressure dramatically, this increase in pressure pushes down on the piston.

An explosion happens much faster and is what's happening when you hear knocking and pinging (pinking) with older engines or the wrong fuel grade in high performance engines.

I watched one of their videos about a week ago. I asked a question in their comments that might be beyond their scope. I'm hoping you can help me out here Destin.

I've been thinking about hydrogen powered internal combustion engines for a while now. They would burn clean, creating power and water that can be reclaimed and electrolyzed into hydrogen and oxygen to start the whole process over again. I understand back when internal combustion engines were first created that this was tried, but the chamber remained too hot, and the hydrogen combusted too soon, creating backfires. Since then, we have improved the efficiency of engines many times over in terms of power versus weight. What if we increased the number of strokes on an engine from 4, intake, compression, power, exhaust, to 8, intake (fuel), compression, power, exhaust, intake (water), exhaust, intake (water again), exhaust. All 3 exhaust strokes would output to a holding tank for water where it would be electrolyzed the next time the vehicle "fuels up" at a charging station. The water intake strokes would pull from the same holding tank. I mentioned the efficiency of engines, because I realize this would take more cylinders than what we're currently used to just to work at all. I'm not a mechanic, but I think that means it would need 8 cylinders minimum to power something small like a 2-door commuter vehicle, where a four stroke would only need 4 cylinders. What do you think, would that work? Would that cool the piston compartment enough to keep the hydrogen from spontaneously combusting? Do we gain enough from burning clean fuel to account for the loss of efficiency?

For background, I live in an area where electricity turning a motor, simply doesn't cut it. Electric vehicles lack the power needed to go up steep, unpaved terrain, especially when said terrain is coated with 6-30 inches of snow. Besides, not everybody wants or can use a small commuter vehicle. People still buy trucks because they need that versatility and power. Electric vehicles haven't even begun to look into meeting that demand. I'm hoping a hydrogen-powered internal combustion engine can present the best of both worlds.

It bothered me a bit that you kept talking about explosions happening inside the engine, when in fact that is the last thing you want in almost any type of engine.

Explosions are actually really harmful to internal combustion engines (it's called detonations or knocking, caused by premature ignition either from incorrect timings, hot spots in the cylinder, or using too high compression with low octane fuel that doesn't have sufficient compression rating), and if they happen inside your car engine you might still get to the work that day but in long-term, they will damage the engine and make it last a shorter time.

And if you're on a spacecraft where there's an explosion in the rocket engine, you're having a bad problem and will not go to space today.

I realize that colloquially it makes sense to use the term "explosion" but perhaps you could make a video about the difference between combustion (the general term for the chemical reaction), conflagration, and explosion (with a detonation front)?

Or, if you want to continue on engines, you could outline how the ignition system of petrol engines and diesel engines differs... and how self-ignition becomes a problem when you increase the compression or manifold pressure on an engine, and what different methods there are to make engines work with higher and higher manifold pressures... like intercooling or anti-detonant injection systems.

after heating (explosion) the pressure of gas inside the engine will rise up .
if the engines intake gas has 100 Kpa pressure
and temp is 311'K or 38'C
and comparison rate is for example 10 to 1
Cv is 700 j/kg
Cp is 1000 j/kg
Qh is 1000 kj/kgc
then Gama is Cp/Cv= 1000/700= 1.43
in compression stroke : p2/p1=R^GAMA => p2/100kpa = 10^1.43 => P2= 2691.53 Kpa (p2 is pressure after compression )
now we have to calculate the T
T2/T1=R^Gama-1 => T2/311=10^0.43=> T2=837.06' K or 564.06' C

now we have all of the factors we need to calculate the explosion stroke :
first we need T3 (temp after explosion) : Qh=mcv(t3-t2)=>T3 = 1992.63'C (it is cilicious or it is 2265.63' Kelvin)
so P2/T2=P3/T3 => 2691.53/837.06=P3/2265.63 => P3= 7285.03 Kpa ( P3 is pressure after explosion)
so you can see the pressure went to much high this is why your engine will run . and this is why when the EX valve went open the Explosion gas will scape form there very fast .
100 Kpa is atmosphere pressure and the pressure inside the engine after explosion is 7285.03 Kpa so 73 times is higher than atmosphere .

Two things: One you can see the "lost spark" when the magneto fires on intake: without compression, the air/fuel mixture can't ignite (and it doesn't). Two: During the exhaust stroke, you can see the exhaust gasses rush out when the valve opens. However, the efficiency of that behavior will be different at different engine RPMs, Internal combustion engines are essentially air pumps, and pumps have an ideal operating RPM. It is possible to time not only the spark, but the opening and closing of the intake and exhaust valve to alter the timing of the engine to make it more efficient at lower or higher RPMs. The term used is cylinder intake and exhaust "scavenging": the air fuel mixture coming into the engine has a certain velocity (and mass).. the shape and length of the intake passage, and the temperature of the air/fuel mixture will determine at what RPM the cylinder scavenges most efficiently on the intake stroke; likewise the exhaust gas temperature, exhaust passage shape and length will determine at what RPM the cylinder scavenges most efficiently on the exhaust stroke. Matching the optimum intake and exhaust scavenging to the same RPM will have the engine perform dramatically more efficiently (and run cleaner to boot) at that RPM. There are a lot more nuances to engine performance... countless man and machine hours have been spent on this subject. It is fascinating to see it happen before your very eyes. Just a quick thing: It's combustion, not explosion.

Explosions are bad in an engine. Explosions will burn the air/fuel mixture too quicky, making the pressure rise quicker than the piston can move downwards. This is also known as engine knock. The result of this will be bent piston rods among other issues.

Summed up: The combustion in an engine is very fast, but it can't be allowed to become too fast.

Destin, Great video and narrative, equally impressive mechanical work by your hosts! Thanks. One small nit on the repeated use of the work "explosion" to describe the beginning of the power stroke. This is more accurately described as a combustion event. Understanding this as "combustion" helps understand the thermo dynamics of the 4 stroke engine. The combustion of the fuel air mixture is initiated by a spark that rapidly heats the air in the combustion chamber. Your awesome high speed video shows a controlled flame front moving starting at the spark and propagating through the combustion chamber. The heated air expands, pushing the piston down and is still expanding slightly as the exhaust valve opens...which is why you see the hot gases rushing out the moment the exhaust valve cracks open. The exhaust stroke then completes the job of pushing out the spent products of combustion. A small nit on an excellent video....apologies if too detailed.

On the topic of internal combustion engines, I have a proposal for a new video. What always was interesting for me was to see a visualization of the volume of the fuel that is consumed during a full cycle, or in a minute, or per distance unit - in different rpm's. Of course I can calculate the volume of my engine, the compression ratio, the air/fuel ratio and the rpm's to derive the actual fuel volume (and air volume also - and exhaust gases volume) but a visualization would be very interesting and educational. Actually thinking about this made drive less aggressive (and age of course!).
You see, I drive my car every day and whenever I visit the pump I try to think how 20 liters of gasoline keeps my engine running for a few days. What is consumed and how fast. Sometimes I think it would be great to poke a hole in my tank and put a camera in there, then take a long trip and watch how the volume of the gas lowers.
For this video, I wish you had a transparent tank - more of a transparent tube of gasoline actually, while shooting the video to see the consumption of the fuel.
Thank you for this video - and for all the videos!

One fact I would've added though is that the engine shown has a "flathead" style valve layout. So called because the valves are on the side of the piston, which makes the top of the engine (the head) very flat. Modern car engines (since about the 50's) all have the valves mounted over the piston, in the head. This allows for much better airflow and performance, as well as allowing for a much higher compression ratio.

I guess that fact isn't super important, but it's kind of interesting.

There used to be a great setup at one of the universities / colleges in Kent (UK).
They had a Ford V6 fuel injection engine.
They had rigged up the engine with a video camera into the inside of the combustion chamber, so they could study the 'cloud' of fuel particles that was injected into the engine. The idea being to see if there was an 'optimal' (a butter zone) nozzle to use on the injectors for improved performance (fuel usage / power etc).
I'm sure you will find something similar in the US somewhere. It was equally cool.

But there is one thing that gets on my nerves... there are no explosions inside of an engine... it's called an internal COMBUSTION engine for a reason. You have to understand that an explosion is violent and mostly uncontrolled. If there was an explosion in that little briggs with the acrylic head you would have lots of little acrylic pieces to pick out of your face since an explosion would destroy the engine completely. A combustion is much more controlled and way slower than an explosion. I know it is hard to fathom since it all happens so fast at actual speed but please understand this : there are no explosions in a n internal combustion engine, only combustions...

Great video and cool high speed camera work. I wish he wouldn't use the word "explosion" though as it not really what is happening. It is a fast "burn" of the fuel/air mixture and you see the flame front across the top of the piston. Engine manufacturers go to great lengths to keep the fuel/air mixture from "exploding" through the design and timing of the spark,ect  If it exploded the mixture it would soon destroy the engine. An explosion is more or less instantaneous causing the pressure to rise sharply and very fast. A burn is slower and the pressure steadily rises in the combustion chamber making the engine run much smoother. Remember also that Briggs & Stratton engine they are using is a very primitive engine as well. Great demonstration and thanks for the effort to show it all to us.

This is really cool. It's easy to see hear why we don't use flat head engines anymore. With the valves in the block, the exhaust has to change direction twice, reducing efficiency. And the explosion dosn't happen directly over the cylinder. Which I am sure is partly due to the fact that the fuel density is at it's lowest directly above the cylinder.

With modern engines, the valve and spark plugs are directly over the cylinder. The exhaust can leave the cylinder without changing direction and the explosion happens directly over the cylinder. Which I would imagine is much more efficient.

I don't know why, but it bothers me when people refer to what goes on in a combustion chamber as an explosion. To me, the word explosion implies that it was uncontrolled. Air is 78% nitrogen. Nitrogen (and all gasses for that matter) expands when heated. All that's happening when the air/fuel mixture is ignited is the oxygen and fuel act as the heating agent, causing the expansion of the nitrogen, forcing the piston down/potato out. It is essentially an air compressor running in reverse but powered with fire. The roar is nothing but the sound of those incredibly hot, fast moving gasses being forced thru a tube designed to make it sound a certain way.
